instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.CHGR_CSI_P: What is CHGR_CSI_P? CHGR_CSI_P is one of the current sense lines for the charger. Resistance between CHGR_CSI_P and CHGR_CSI_N should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 20.02 ohms.
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
Hi,

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is looping between 12.25 and 12.57V on an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>).

Also the output of the USB-C ports are weird. 
- 19.4V
- 0.00-0.04A
I assume the CD3215s are fine because I get 20V, right? 

What should I check next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message: Check for voltage (pulse at least) on the big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
I have checked the SLPS2R + AWAKE (all present).

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE = 0.8V
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 0.75V

<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.8V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.57V (should be fine)
USB-C Output = 19.4V / 0.04A (DFU Mode - Since when is 0.04A DFU Mode? I thought 0.07A is DFU mode?!)

i have also tried via <SIGNAL>FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> + <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> (usb c output 19.4V / 0.08A)

In DFU mode <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> isn't pulsing / looping.
Note: I can't restore the device via AC2 error message:

"Gave up waiting for device to transition from DFU state to DFU state. [com.apple.MobileDevice.MobileRestore - 0xFCA (4042)]"

Please don't tell me that the T2 is bad. :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message: Do you get all G3S and SSD voltages too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
I have accidentally shorted <CAPACITOR>C7080</CAPACITOR> (PIN1 = <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>) and <CAPACITOR>C7021</CAPACITOR> (PIN1 = <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSI_P</SIGNAL>) with my multimeter tip .....
No short on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSI_P</SIGNAL> but now I only get 5.02V and 0.05A on all four USB-C ports ....
Comparing the <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> diode value to a good known board is the same (0.412).

But why the hell im getting now 5.02V and 0.05A (sending outwards to the charger) on the USB-C port?
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.9-1.1V (did I broke my ISL?)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
"Comparing the <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> diode value to a good known board is the same (0.412)."
Did the same for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

Nothing will wotk, if no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
So I have replaced the ISL .... im now getting 12.57V (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>) again. (so yeah I fucked with that short my ISL - was kinda stupid :D)

But here we go...

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

<SIGNAL>I2C_SSD_SCL</SIGNAL> = 0.7V
<SIGNAL>I2C_SSD_SDA</SIGNAL> = 1.8V

Note:
- Trackpad is clicking
- In DFU mode <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.25V is that normal?
- While restoring BridgeOS it is looping between 12.25 and 12.57V, any idea?

Edit:
Here a video of the usb c output:
[MEDIA=imgur]a/8cvYLVE[/MEDIA]

Edit2: 
Diode mode value from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (working board) = 0.412
Im getting 0.372 .... can be ignored?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
In DFU mode, T2 firmware is supposed to be reflashed; it can't control <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> all this time.

Even no short to ground present at <SIGNAL>1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>, this doesn't discard a damage on some chip powered from this power rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
What else should I check?

Edit: I mean itâ€™s the same behavior in the AC2 before and after the short (made by me).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
"Do you get all G3S and SSD voltages too?"

Did you try both revive/restore?

threads.message: Yes both.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message: Probably problem with T2, or SSD...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
that sucks â€¦ already the third MacBook with a T2 or SSD issue.

Edit: Is it normal that in DFU mode that the usb c output goes up to 20V?

Edit2: The battery is also not charging correctly which means the current goes up to "0.15A, 0.35A, 0.55A and 0.70A" and than it gets reseted to 0.00A. (starts again)
Could be a faulty CD my issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message: <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips should be good, if all ports switch to 20V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
I have tested it again restoring BridgeOS while the logicboard is in the housing â€¦. All four ports are doing when the battery is connected â€¦

Note: Issue only occurs when the battery is connected.
[MEDIA=imgur]a/XwjSrXf[/MEDIA]

Edit: 
- With battery ... PPBUS = 11V (stable) - USB-C output issue
- Without ... 12.57V (not stable) - USB-C output no issue

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
So <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuates with charger alone?
Check for short on all big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
Yeah, CPU coils have low resistance to ground as normal.

Do you get stable voltage at L7660/90?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
I assume you mean "L7660" and "L7600".

L7660 (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>) = 3.3V (stable)
L7600 (<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>) = 1.3 - 5.1V (not stable)

Edit:
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> is also pulsing (0-3.3V) .. so thats possible the reason why <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> isnt stable.
Source of <SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> is <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>? (Bad <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>?)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
Do you have original 87W charger?
Check G3S voltages with both charger and battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
yeah itâ€™s an OEM one.

The USB-C adapter screen is just flashing (on / off) â€¦. And no G3S voltages.

Edit: What is that noise? (Last couple of seconds of the video) It occurred after the USB-C went off.

[MEDIA=imgur]a/VTt8Zn7[/MEDIA]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
Same behaviour on all ports?
Usually meter restarts when the board try to start and smoething trigger SMC protection.
Check if starts in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
Yeah same behavior on all four ports.
How to do a SMC bypass on a T2 board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
Press power button 5s and maintain it pressed.
Connect charger and release power button after 10s, or when you hear the fans starting.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
Doesnâ€™t work. 

Edit: The USB-C voltage meter screen is only turning on/off when I have the cable for DFU mode restore connected to my MacBook (AC2).
Any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:
Try DFU restore without connecting charger.
Use RE032 pads to force it, instead of keyboard.

threads.message: Already tried that, same AC2 error message.

If you want to insist, change <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>...

Video:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping
threads.message:

Edit:

- 5V / 0.16A | <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.27V
- 19.4V / 0.04A | <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is slowly going down from 5V to 0V

Did you ever seen such a behaviour?
